author: {'steamid': '76561198038512148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5029, 'last_played': 1433634300}
review:
There's something special about guiding a mechanical monster through a city, setting fire to whole neighbourhoods and reducing landmarks to rubble.  Especially in your hometown.

The premise of the game is pure over-the-top grandeur, and conveyed comic-book style with tongue-deeply-planted-in-cheek.  You are a socially-challenged scientist with a secret island facility, where resides your ultimate robotic creation, basically Heavy Metal Godzilla.  Your goal is to demoralize the citizens of the world, one city or region at a time, using threats and destruction, until they submit to your rule.  They will not do so easily, though, defending their cities with troops and vehicles of all sorts, and occasionally raiding your base to take down the villain at the heart of all their misery.

The sheer fun of city destruction is balanced against base-building, weapon development and resource collection.  

To say that I've enjoyed playing this game is an understatement.  I get a little rush of excitement every time the Kerberos logo pops up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065094838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 2522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1923, 'last_played': 1470041483}
review:
怪獣を操り、街を破壊して都市を服従させて世界征服！というゲーム
破壊した街から資材を奪い、怪獣を改造し、はたまた悪の秘密基地も要塞化し地球防衛軍から守りぬけ！とディフェンス要素もあったり・・・
簡単に言うと「世界征服するクセしてちまちま侵略するな」って感じのゲーム

怪獣を操って街を破壊するって割に大分トロトロと侵略するので、「怪獣を使って世界征服！」と意気揚々思ってプレイするとやってられません。
初期の怪獣の性能はメチャクチャ悪いです、動きも遅く街を移動するのにも時間がかかり、そのうえ攻撃力も低いので行く手を阻む建物を破壊するにも時間がかかり面倒にかなり感じます。
もちろん街を破壊すると敵、ここで言う「防衛軍」がやってきますが、これも的が小さく動きが早いのでターゲットするのに苦労します、そのうえ建物の間をランダムに縫うように動き、建物を重なると狙うことすら出来ません。
そして上にも書いたように技の威力も低いので、序盤から敵を倒すのも一苦労。そしてターゲッティングも悪く、なかなか敵にあたってくれません。戦車だよ戦車！なんで建物狙ってんだよ！

シム要素、タワーディフェンスもありますが、これのせいでかなりチマチマと侵略しないといけない面倒なシステムになっています。
街を侵略し、破壊すると資材をゲット出来るのですが、到底ここだけで手に入る資材だけではやりくり出来ず、秘密基地に発電所やら研究所やら建てないと足りません。そのくせ維持費まで取る。踏み倒せよ悪の科学者！
序盤から考えて秘密基地を改造していかないと中盤に差し掛かる前に詰むことになります。秘密基地防衛戦は敵が強く数も多い上に、秘密基地の施設は防衛不可能、怪獣も操って防衛するのですが怪獣の攻撃で壊れる方が多いくらいでどうしようもありません。

そしてなにより気に入らないのは「いつまでも怪獣が弱い！」
怪獣は改造して強くなるのですが、基本的にステータスは全くイジれず、技・スキルの付け替えだけで戦わなければならないのですが、弱い！弱すぎる！
序盤はどれも使い勝手が悪い上に怪獣のHPは低いので、ちょっとやられたらすぐ逃げ帰って来ないと行けないのがイライラ！
中盤になってHPアップや電磁シールド、広範囲にダメージを与えれるスキルがてにはいりますが、その頃には防衛軍がそれを上回る物量と攻撃力で必滅です。悪の科学者が防衛軍の開発力下回ってんじゃねーぞ・・・

と言っても終盤になれば、怪獣は一撃で街を火の海に変えるほどの火力を持ち、モニター一面真っ赤になる様はかなり爽快です・・・ですが、そこまでの道のりはかなり遠く最初から怪獣で暴れ回りたいと思ってる方には全くオススメ出来ません。

review:
Lets get the bad things out of the way so we can get to the fun stuff.
1) There are some glitches, a few maps have terraquatic battleships for instance.
2) It can be a little bit difficult to auto target aircraft.

That's it. Seriously, that's all I can complain about. The first thing is actually hilarious to watch in action, and the second is easily solved by manually right clicking on an enemy and using an ability.

So the good stuff: This game is hilarious. You get to play a Kaiju, an enormous mechanical Godzilla-like robot with lazer eyes, fire breath and a whole slew of abilities to lay waste to all in your path. There are some strategical points to consider (which makes the game fun and adds a bit of a challenge) such as funding for your base in the form of money, biomatter and research. You can build and customize your base, choosing from facilites to generate power, resaerch and food or to train your Kaiju. 

Attacking the cities of the world is enormously enjoyable, you can destroy famous landmarks (over and over) and fight anything from infantry to lazer tanks and battleships. The longer you stay in a city, the more dangerous it becomes but you might be able to capture it. Captured cities = money so it can be worth the risk.

Either way, this game is extremely fun and worth a look at whether you like a bit of over the top destructon or a fine tuned strategy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038851797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 19616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12724, 'last_played': 1592236164}
review:
TLDR: Surprisingly deep game for strategy gamers. Good solid fun for casual gamers, especially ones who love being bad guys.

Having spent so many hours playing this game, I felt like it was about time I wrote a review.

I'm always interested in games which you can play from the 'opposite point of view'. Games like Evil Genius, or Stubbs the Zombie, or Dungeon Keeper, where you can take on the role of the traditional 'bad guy'.

This game lets you take control of a city wrecking Kaiju in your bid to take over the world. Some people have made the comparison to the old school arcade classic Rampage, but this game is so much more intricate and has so much more depth. It's hard to compare it to anything else I can think of. It has base building elements, character development as you power up your Kaiju, strategy at a city level and global level. Resource management. Although you could play it as a casual city stomping experience, if you invest more time and attention in the game, you will come to appreciate the depth here.

At a secret base level, you have to juggle your resources and facilities, making raids to gather all the money and power and organics to maintain your base and build new facilities. You will have a couple of years to build up your base and Kaiju powers before the Kaiju Defence Force (KDF) begin to attack your secret base directly. But when they do, you'd better have some defences in place because even their first attacks can send enough units to wreck your base and overwhelm your Kaiju.

At a global level, there are many cities rated from Tier 1 (weak) to Tier 5 (strong), and spread across 6 global regions. Each attack on a city will raise the alert level of a region, from green to yellow to amber to red. It's much easier to catch a city off guard in a region with a low alert level, and the alert level will drop over time if you don't keep attacking the same region. On the other hand, you can capture cities faster with repeated attacks, but doing so will leave a region on Red Alert level, which I've never seen drop back down to amber, even after several in game months. Attacking cities which are on alert makes your raid much tougher as there will be more units on the map to greet you. Catching a city off guard will give you some time to stomp around without any enemies to oppose you. That can make a big difference.

The only way to force a city to surrender without plunging the whole region to red alert is to hit it when the region is on green alert, completely unprepared, and make it surrender with one attack. That adds a level of strategy. If you have no regions on green alert, do you risk a raid and force that region to an even higher alert level, or take a break, maybe spend some time training new abilities until the regions calm down again? Or do you just attack relentlessly and pay no heed to the alert levels, risking being ambushed when you arrive at a city, or facing a lot of enemy units as soon as you arrive, instead of catching them by surprise and having some time to wreck whatever you wish without having to fight off the defence forces?

At a city level, each city has its own character. The developers have made each city look like it should with the building styles and map layout, and each city has a different selection of units to protect it. Some rely more on helicopters and aircraft, some have more tanks, or hi tech units, some use lighter long ranged units like missile trucks and missile tanks. Each kind of enemy unit requires a different kind of Kaiju power to counter. And with only 6 power slots available, picking the right abilities for each city is important. No point taking normal Eye Beam Lasers when you know you're going to be facing tanks. You'll need Radioactive Death Stare for those. But then again, if you're only going to be facing jeeps and light tanks, normal Eye Beams are much more useful, they cost less power to use, and have a much quicker recharge time. No need for overkill, always picking the most powerful abilities you have.

Also, each city has a different balance of available resources. Some cities might have many colleges and universities, making it a great place to raid for Knowledge. Others might have several banks or large office building areas, great for looting cash. Some have extensive dock and port areas, where you can get plenty of energy. Some cities might not have many buildings where you can get power, so you'll have to make sure you head out with plenty of power already in your Kaijus batteries. Others might have so many power buildings that you can afford to go there running on empty, so you can bring back to base a huge amount of power for building better facilities.

Either way, even though you have a massive monster under your control, you will inevitably be overwhelmed and forced to retreat as the defenders send more and more units against you. So you have to hit a city hard, grab what you need, destroy your chosen targets and get out again safely. Do you want to force the city to surrender and supply you with monthly cash income? Take out their landmarks and stomp on as many civilians as you can. Are you just making a raid for cash, or power, or knowledge? Find the buildings that contain what you need, and smash them to the ground to get at the goodies inside. Banks, Universities, Power Plants, Office Towers... they all give up more loot than simple houses and stores.

You can definitely play this as a casual stress relief kind of game, having fun stomping on fleeing citizens and infantry, swatting helicopters out of the sky and melting tanks with laser beams and plasma breath, but for players who love deeper strategy and unique or unusual gameplay, this game really has a lot to offer.

And with the upcoming release of two more Kaiju, with different abilities and features, it has more to offer in the future. I can understand why some players are disappointed that all three monsters weren't available at launch, but the develpers have been toiling hard behind the scenes, as well as polishing the game as it stands with tweaks, bug hunts and game balancing. Over 200 hours with only one Kaiju, and two more to look forward to. I didn't play Skyrim or Fallout 3 as much as I've played this, and those two games are definitely on my top 5 list of most awesome games.

2016/11/24更新
戰鬥中的操控其實不大流暢

地面上的各種會移動的戰車載具 很容易誤擊建築或平民而讓目標高速逃逸

天上飛的戰鬥機轟炸機等則會因為是2D遊戲 難以分辨飛行單位的相對位置來抓位置使用近戰攻擊

導致戰鬥方面很不痛快


而滑鼠右鍵則是施放特定技能時的輔助鎖定   像是投射物 光線系 飛彈 砲擊 觸手穿刺類的攻擊
事先用右鍵鎖定目標後 使用技能時 AI會朝著有藍色鎖定標誌的目標發動技能

author: {'steamid': '76561197970017778', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1493265770}
review:
Thus far, I've been having quite an enjoyable time with this game.   One of the main reasons I first became interested was due to the look.  Immediately I was struck by how similar it was to an old game I enjoyed (also a monster destroying the city type game), The Movie Monster Game (C64).  the only difference being you directly controlled the monster in the C64 title, while in Kiaju-A-Go Go you have basic control over direction and what building to attack, but not true direct 1:1 control.

This game can be a bit of a grind to get your Kaiju built up.  Though if things were easy you'd probably not keep playing.  The game requires you to balance upgrades, buildings which come in numerous categories (such as production, training, storage, defense and the like) against your current monthly upkeep budget.  You can steal resources simply by attacking cities.  If you should manage to get one to surrender you will receive a monthly infusion of cash from that city.

Cities come in multiple difficulties.  So you will have to upgrade your Kaiju to tackle anything more than the basic level 1 cities (which can still be a challenge if you're only working with level 1 and 2 upgrades).  You do get plenty of upgrades to choose from once you've build all of the upgraded training facilities for your Kaiju.  So fret not, mad scientist. 

Aesthetically, the game looks quite good while still retaining the isometric camera view that games like The Movie Monster game utilized back in the mid 80's.  Cities look very nice at night, and you can zoom in or out to quite some degree.  The game also runs for me without a hitch, and on an older gaming rig (Core 2 Quad @ 3.72GHz, 8GB 1066MHz RAM, and Radeon HD6970 2GB video card) that's in sore need of an upgrade.

So, if you don't think there are nearly enough Kaiju games where you get to rampage through a city.  You have a few extra bucks and are looking to spend some cash on something fun.  This is your game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059561891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1465095276}
review:
When I was younger. I played a game with my brother. It was called Rampage. I have fond memories of that game, smashing buildings and general chaos. Alas I grew up and those games seemingly have been forgotten by time. This genre needs to make a come back and Kaiju-A-GoGo may be the start of it. The goal is simple, world domination. Is it easy? No. Is it fun? Yes. Is it repetitious? Sadly, yes. 
Kaiju-A-GoGo is a sound video game on paper. Kaiju attacks city, gets resources, takes said resources back to base for upgrades and base expansion. However there is certain things that just hold the game back from being amazing. Controls are abysmal. Base management is more  a chore then actually fun. The long grind to getting your Kaiju up and running with powers. Despite this though, Kaiju-A-GoGo is still a really fun game. The moments you find yourself blasting lasers, fire, or god knows what. Watching everything explode around you is blissfully giddy and captures that giant monster magic. With more Kaiju monsters coming and PLENTY of abilities and upgrades. You have plenty of bang for your buck. The graphics and music are just fine as well. I want this genre to come back and Kaiju-A-GoGo can make it happen. With some patches and changes.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/gu2S_weuZes
I hope you enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010551271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2035, 'last_played': 1491849954}
review:
TL DR version;  About as good as Super Godzilla on the snes, except a hell of a lot more grindier.  

I played this through all the way to the finish for a very underwhelming game ending.  There weren't even any credits!  I dug around in the files and found some cool unused music in the soundtrack which left me dissappointed as it would of made the end game sound a lot more fun.  Especially when you start to actually fight things that are your size (which is both boring and a bit more tedious since you can't target them like you can everything else.).
All in all, the game could be a hell of a lot better.  And I don't see them changing the way the game plays.  The small buildings give you trouble through out most of the game until you're stronger.  But that really just pads out the length of the game and makes it boring.  It would of been better if you could just simply smash through anything small from the start and having to use your abilities on the larger buildings.  And having to use the stomp animation on civillians and infantry makes it hard to run away from getting killed, they should just die when you move over them instead.  I was also expecting some back and forth dialogue between the mad scientist and the likes of the ultraman and power ranger knock offs.  Also the game liked to crash a lot when you fought these types of enemies.

Also forgot to mention, you'll be doing a whole lot of waiting while you upgrade your kaiju.  Sounds really bad to complain having to wait 1-2 minutes of your time for a video game.  But it all adds up, and you'll be spending a lot of time either looking at your island base or at the world map.

review: A deceptively simple interface (point and click to devastate everything in your path, half a dozen hotkeys to unleash nuclear fires, deathrays or other monstrocities of super-science) hides a steady stream of tactical decisions. Chase down those fleeing civilians to crush your enemies will to resist your power? Crush that annoying APC that's been plinking away at your health all the way through suburban Seattle? Chase down that helicopter that keeps buzzing you and watch it crash into an office block, engulfing it in flames? Turn back to loot the mall that burnt down after you casually set it aflame in passing? Or press on to finally smash the Space Needle that dares to rival the height of your precious creation? Defend your monster by crushing the forces sent against it, but leave the city mostly intact, or recklessly risk having to rebuild your monster and lose a rampage's worth of loot by pressing on to rob that research lab of its secrets, heedless of the armies dogging your heels? Interesting gameplay is usually about making choices, and if you want those choices to involve laying waste to the cities of the Earth because it seemed like a reasonable thing to do at the time, Kaiju-A-GoGo is for you.

DO NOT BE INTIMIDATED WITH THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS.

Many of the negative reviews are talking about the launch and people who don't understand the controls. Indeed the game was in a rough shape on the launch, with crashes and bugs, but it's perfectly fine right now and being updated with frequency! The devs are very attentive and quick to act about any problems that show up! 

From the creators of a marvelous game that I love too (Swords of the Stars: The Pit), this gem is perfect for those who are fan of kaijus (giant monsters) and strategy games.

In this game, you have to plan how to upgrade your kaiju (it even changes his appearance in some upgrades!) and your secret island, to help your efforts in taking over the world.

Destroy cities and make them surrender their command to you, making them vassal states.

Fight against air, ground, sea military forces and even other kaijus that will try to stop you!
And most important: Have tons of fun doing that.

The game controls can be a bit frustrating in the beginning, and the targeting of some attacks may look confuse, but with a little time and patience, you'll get in to it! Just keep in mind that you're controling a giant monster in a city, and that pesky tank you're trying to hit with your Eye Beam may be behind a building or something, and remember to lock the target on them with the right mouse button! :)

By the time, there's only one kaiju, but there are 2 to be released as dlc (for free for those who buy before their release!) and they plan to release more after the 3 initial ones, and maybe even a expansion!

So what you're waiting for? Buy it and go cause some mayhem!

author: {'steamid': '76561198084203609', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1429936547}
review:
SUMMARY: Though it has its heart in the right place, Kaiju-A-GoGo is a game that just doesn't offer enough to do it's great idea and design justice.  Repetitive play, clunky design, and a feeling of being unfinished get in the way of the fun.

Kaiju-A-GoGo is a kind of reverse X-Com or reverse Defend The Planet type game.  You're the force of evil that threatens the world, and it's your goal to conquer it while others try and stop you.  They will, of course, fall before your might.

The game itself is a mixture of Kaiju stomper/environment destroyer, RPG, resource gatherer, and evil base management.  You send your Kaiju forth to devestate cities, gather resources while you traumatize the population into submission, and then upgrade your base.  As cities fall before you, they send tribute to further fuel your efforts - which you'll need as forces rally to stop you.

The game comes down to:
1) Send a Kaiju to a city, and use a simple point and click method, plus various powers, to cause havok.  Gather resources as you smash and conquer.
2) Use resource to upgrade your Kaiju.
3) Use resources to upgrade your base (including deciding on geographic layout).
4) Repeat until you conquer the world.

Unfortunately, the game's various pieces don't line up:
1) Combat feels clunky and repetitive - point, crush, lookt, continue.  It moves slow, targeting is iffy, and environments get samey very quickly.
2) Kaiju Upgrading takes time, though there is an extensive upgrade system for those who get deep into the game.
3) Base management has some strange interface issues, but mostly comes down to trying to clear land and build structures with resources.  There's not a lot of guidance or help to determining your path (some simple projections would help)

The game ends up being less fun, more management, rather slow, and not that exciting - and there's not a lot of initial guidance on the gameplay that make a lot of it a case of stabbling in the dark.

Though the game is, simply, very flawed and unpolished, I do have to credit the great art style and the enthusiasm.  There's a kind of cartoony vibe provided to the game, with amusing character designs and a real sense of humor.  It's a game that feels "right" - until you play it.

The designers seem very commited to the game, promising new monsters and updates.  That gives me some hope as it shows promise, but it's not there yet.  It feels very Early Access - and not in a good way.

So I have some hope - but for now, take a pass, unless you truly want to relive the old days of Crush, Crumble, and Chomp or The Creature That Ate Sheboygan.  The game has a way to go, it's a bit of a monster of the wrong kind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106444148', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1430176694}
review:
Don't feel like reading? Check out the video! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dMnCUX5pbEE&feature=youtu.be 
Don't forget to subscribe!

Just the name of this game has you wondering what it could be about. Abound with curiosity, diving in head first might not always be the best idea. What claims to be an homage to City destroyers of yester year, ends up making us wish this game remained in that time. Kaiju-a-GoGo has a somewhat creative concept but, does having a game with giant city destroying monsters automatically make it worth your time?

	With basically zero tutorial you are dropped into the intro of the game. Some characters flash on the screen only long enough to become annoying, and to tell you that you’re about to unleash your monster on Anchorage. This may seem like a fine way to teach you game mechanics, but the only mechanics really to teach are click where to go, and automatically destroy things along the way. Each building you destroy gives out some type of resource that is indicated by a symbol. Batteries, Books, Crystals, Money, and Chicken legs; are the resources dropped when buildings are destroyed. It is not immediately, or eventually apparent what each of these symbols represents. Chicken legs are to represent bio fuel in this game; I guess an oil drum was to confusing.

	After returning from your first outing with your loot, It is quickly taken from you in the form of expenses for your secret base. These expenses include operating costs mostly, but you can spend your ill-gotten gains on upgrades for your facility. Your monster needs time to recover from its last endeavour; giving you time to explore your island. 

	Your mad scientist utopia starts covered in jungle that your need to periodically remove. Using the resources that your monster gathers from the destroyed cities, you can build facilities that will allow you to improve your monsters abilities and better defend your island. Defending your island is essential as armies from vengeance seeking countries will come looking for a fight. For the most part you build facilities that produce resources which you use to build more facilities; making this process somewhat of a grind. Other structures include warehouses that give you a bigger max capacity for specific units. It never feels like you will be hitting your capacity but, players who do a lot of grinding could eventually run into this problem.

	Essentially the game is a kind of cycle where you use your monster to destroy cities, use the resources to build up your facilities, which in turn makes your monster better at destroying cities. For some this might be seen as a grind, and it certainly feels like one too. Your monster has a capacity for how many resources it can carry back from a city. This makes the progression incredibly slow paced, and feels like an intentional way to stretch out the game. You’ll increasingly feel the futility every time you come back to your island with such a small amount of loot.

	All of these problems resemble something that you would find on Facebook, rather than Steam. In fact the entire game reeks of a freemium online and mobile game. The resources you collect are over simplified, the monsters power ups are few and far between, and the improvements you make to your island take time to be completed. Your monster also needs time to be repaired between destructions. Granted there is an in game clock that you can manipulate to make faster or slower but, this seems like an online flash game with real time waiting periods that has been adapted for a full release. This kind of game design is essentially flawed. Constructing a game that is designed to waste time and make money, isn’t the way to release a full game on Steam. It also feels like that’s how they landed on this rather expensive price tag. The price you pay on steam must factor in what they think the average person online spends on this game over their playtime; but that’s just a theory.

	Besides being a cash grab some of the artwork is okay. It resembles the first Plants vs. Zombies, with a colourful hand drawn art style. Although where PvZ was over the top and cartoony, this game sits on the fence between cartoon and reality. Not picking a side in this matter becomes problematic. The art style wants to tell a quirky story while some of the dialogue contradicts it with references to real world cities. I think this game could reach the same kind of audience as PvZ, if they would just play up the wackiness of the concept. For instance, your monster looks like something out of a kids cartoon; thumbs up. But the building you destroy are obviously illustrated with a certain level of realism. The cities you destroy look more out of SimCity then what I would expect a skyline to look like in a kids show; thumbs down. Overall the artwork has potential, but looks cheap and is cheapened by the animations. The monster moving doesn’t look very convincing, in fact it just looks like twinked animation. Not something that most people would really notice while destroying a city, but it’s so bad it’s distracting

On the whole this is a game for kids. I guess it’s not really something to aspire to, selling a game to kids who don’t know that it’s worse than any other game from the 90’s and early 2000’s. Ultimately I would give a child Roller Coaster Tycoon, also available on Steam for less money, before I gave him something as confusing as this mess of menus. That’s not a knock on RCT, it’s legitimately an entertaining game for all age groups. This game just fails on the execution of its gameplay; and if a game isn’t fun to play then whose going to play it. Games that grind are fun when it’s amounting to something, but this just doesn’t ever seem worthwhile. Your money would be much better spent on either game aforementioned in this review. We just wish this monster never reared its ugly head.

review:
[h1]Kaiju-A-GoGo Is your typical underdelivering indie game.[/h1]
[i]The kind you cant wait to be 'finished'.[/i]

Heres a quick run down why that is at the moment:
[olist]
[*]It doesnt look remotely good even for a sprite based game.
[*]It runs horribly and crashes are common.
[*]It's lacking content [i](Theres a story behind that but its irrelevant)[/i]
[*]Its got more than its fair share of bugs, which leads into the next point...
[*]Patches are not tested, coming out and making the game even worse.
[*]The UI is clunky at best.
[*]All the 'strategic' gameplay outside of directly destroying cities seems like its just there to facilitate the city destroying. Those parts of the game havent been executed well at all.
[*]Base building specifically is awkward and slow. If you want to build a wall thats 5 tiles long you would need to click 20 times around your screen. [i](Unless you need to click behind a piece of UI, then youre boned)[/i]
[*]Training new abilities becomes very slow very fast and as you cant use your Kaiju while training new abilities it all feels very discouraging.
[/olist]

And that list could go on further but those are the main issues as I write this.

There are of course some great things in the game, like destroying cities with laser-eye-beams-of-death!
But alas, youre fighting through these issues before, during and after those fun times.

review:
Крики людей, взрывы, горящий город и жуткая вонь горящих и похоронненых под завалами тел, гигантский металлический Кайдзю (если кто не в курсе - монстр, самый известный Кайдзю это если память не подводит Годзилла) систематично сеет хаос и пожар. Время от времени отвлекаясь на то что бы взорвать очередной танк, сбить ударом могучего кулака вертолет или на такое мелкое удовольствие как растоптать возвод пехоты. 

Тебе нравиться то что ты прочитал, хотя воображение рисует ужасные картины? Если да - то тебе сюда, добро пожаловать на Базу Икс, где сумасшедший ученый строит планый по захату мира и создает Кайдзю. Думаю, ты не удивишься если узнаешь, что сумасшедший ученый - это ты сам! Думай, строй, создавай Кайдзю и вперед к власти над миром. В концы концов когда еще появится шанс захватить мир не привлекая излишнего внимания санитаров :)

Теперь читатель ближе к делу: игра лично мне несколько напомнила Икс-Ком, у нас есть база, ряд ресурсов необходимых для ее строительства и научных исследований способностей Кайдзю. Есть еще мир, разделенный на регионы, в которых расположены города (все таки у меня возник вопрос почему - города а не страны). Города в которые мы приходим сеять зло! Управление Кайдзю сносное, древо технологий понятное... Так что вперед сеять доброе и вечное!

PS. После нескольких часов проведенных в игре хотелось бы добавить еще несколько фактов. Во первых у городов есть градация - самые легкие завоевать можно легко и непринужденно. Дальше интереснее, на пути нашего Кайдзю встают на море - патрульные флотилии, на суше - армейские корпуса. Иногда военные способны хорошенько дать прикурить. Да и сами города начинают сопротивляться - от военных истребителей и вертолетов подозрительно похожих на Апачи до орд танков. Ох и тяжкое дело воевать мир!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023507159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1276, 'last_played': 1440104660}
review:
This game is VERY appy.  You have multiple currencies (cash, fuel, flesh, purple stuff, tech) with which you have to buld  a secret base...balancing production and storage of EVERYTHING with defense measures.  Basically this game has every frustrating and meaningless ap convention that "impels" people to grind through pay walls and into brain numbing nirvana...without really needing that.  There are no pay walls. I wonder if there might have been better design choices... like instead of a single Kaiju grinding out 105 abilities to fit into 6 available slots...there could be more specialized kaijus with more managable configurations.  I'd rather be building different kaijus than balancing the books to make sure I'm not going to run out of flesh by the end of the month. The base building part is pretty silly.  

And yet the Kaiju part of the game is a lot of fun.

You'll grow tired of the ridiculous management game long before you grind to tier-5, but the first few tiers are well worth the price.  

There is the basis of a VERY good game here.  With experience and feedback "Kaiju a GoGo 2" will be something to look forward to.  Hopefully future efforts will have more KAIJUs in it and less silly phone ap, spreadsheet management, stuff.

One last thing needs to be addressed.  This game is definitely "hot off the press."  After release there has been many balance patches and the game has wild swings between being too easy to almost impossible.  If the devs don't fix that trend, you'll see this reccomendation quickly turn into a NO.

review:
Incredibly fun, exactly how a 'kaiju' game should be.

It starts very slow, and may seem abit boring, but eventually you'll be dropping tac nukes, calling in drones, and generally obliterating huge areas in true 'kaiju' style, eventually when the other two kaiju get released there'll be more options, but even for now we have a huge variety in a single character.

Just thinking about what I have unlocked in my current game is quite significant, 3 tier 1 abilities, followed by 9 out of 9 tier 2, 12 or so out of 18 third tier, and I can't even remember how many fourth tier, as well as 4 tier 5's. 

Now what does that mean? well I have three types of eye laser, rapid fire blasters, a cluster rocket launcher, a guided cruise missile, drone calls ins a tactical nuclear missile launcher, advanced armor, self repair capability etc. the list goes on. from small passive upgrades to massive options like the "Brimstone" missile, a missile which rains fire on the entire map of a city. The variety, and options in this game are astounding. Definitely worth it's price, and best yet if you buy a copy you'll be garenteeing further support, meaning yet more variety, and options.

Besides the Kaiju though there is also a pretty neat base building mechanic, and witty, comedic commentary on upgrades, and cities n such.

Some achievements are buggy, but other than that I have encountered no bugs/glitches in about 12 hours of play.

review:
I'm going to keep on playing this a bit more and edit this as needed, but here's my current feel for the game.  It needs ...more...  They have a good game foundation built (other than some bugs that can be annoying but not game breaking), but I can see it getting old fairly fast.  After a bunch of runs in to destroy cities, usually about 3-4 per city so far to conquer it all the way, it does gets a little old hat doing the same routine each time.  Especially the early game.

Stomping around in the cities is just left click to move and it auto attacks anything in your path.  Your abilites are tied into the same energy pool of pickups that you want to bring back to your island, so for quite awhile you will be conserving your energy as much as possible.  Makes things feel very slow early on, although later it gets better.

I should also add that it is a bit on the grindy side to the point that cutting build/training times in half would really help kill off the facebook game vibe you get while playing sometimes.   

All that said, I do enjoy playing it.  It is by no means a terrible game, without Rampage around anymore there really isn't much else like this out there.  The graphics are fine, the cities look good with a fair number of different structures in them, and a city on fire at night is flat out beautiful.  It does a great job with the atmosphere and making you feel like a giant monster running amock. 
   
I have no regrets purchasing it but I am leaving my review negative for now simply because this game is not for everyone.  TLDR - Very slow begining, fairly grindy, has a bit of a facebook game feel to it, but fun concept and great in small doses.  Really wish there was more than a YES/NO system honestly, I'd say 7/10 in it's current state.  Will update as they patch the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008715280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1704575038}
review:
Prior to the recent popularity of crowdunded games, this game is what a publisher would call "a loser". Many of us who grew up in the games world of the late 80's and 90's miss the days when a neat concept game would hit the shelves and surprise with something new. For the decade prior, a new game was the latest FPS, RPG or MMO whos distinguishing feature would be how much sharper the graphics are THIS time. Far from perfect, but a lot of fun, Kaiju-A-GoGo is essentially a unique strategy and tactics RPG about destroying cities and conquering the world with a giant robot.

Concept: Rather than state that the game is bad or good because I happen to like it, It would be better to simply describe the product's appeal to me, and let the reader decide if it appeals to him/her as well. The objective is to conquer the world. The game consists of a strategy metagame and of course the tactical destroy-the-city game.

The strategy gameflow is to build up various resources to improve your Kaiju. You only get one. The game has a base building feature to generate resources and train the Kaiju similar to X-com. The Kaiju is improved by adding abilities you research in a tiered structure. Each successive tier features more abilities than the last, causing the player to be more judicious about which abilities he wants to research. 

The tactical game consists of ordering the kaiju to move in a certain direction in the city and using the active abilities for certain effects. The objective is to destroy as much as possible, driving the city's morale down and picking up resources to bring back with you. The lower the morale, the higher the chance the city will surrender. Building types will generate certain types of resources and certain cities have more of some resources than others. As the city wears down, the defenders will grow stronger and the player has to consider the endurance of the Kaiju vs. the his ability to escape or cause a surrender. A surrender is the main way to generate the money resource.

I'm a big fan of this type of gameplay, so this is basically my list of pros. The game is a progressive/grind type of metastrategy game, which does not appeal to everyone. Making the Kaiju stronger and destroying a city is great fun for me, and though the mechanics have some problems, the build up is quite satisfying. 

Now for the problems: 

The Kaiju can be hard to control sometimes and the amount of enemies and congestion makes maneuvering more difficult than it should be. Some common sense changes, such as allowing clicking off map to escape, and scrolling using arrow keys or some alternate method would be helpful. The kaiju also has a tendency to just shoot whatever it wants rather than the intended target. This can be frustrating.

There are some siily bugs, boats on land and at least once, I had an issue where I wouldn't take damage, my shots wouldnt land and the defenders stopped spawning.

Todays gamer needs a much larger amount of handholding than any generation prior, and this game does very little of it. Though the game can be figured out quite easily through trial and error plus deductive reasoning, these players often have youtube accounts with thousands of other easily confused player subscribers. A manual would probably help them enjoy thier game experience better. I don't know, for me the idea that I should look for an escape route for my Kaiju and be prepared to dig through some buildings when I'm at a certain health level...seems common sense to me.

Unfortunately, this small team of developers did not make the game in first person, or use the unreal-whatever engine to generate graphics. If you need these things to enjoy a game [strike]I feel sorry for you[/strike], maybe there will be an action spin-off rail shooter if this game takes off...just for you. The art style won't appeal to everyone, and sprites are a thing of the past, though for some sad reason, creepy not-really-lifelike awkward 3d models of people are not.

Thousands of people that have wasted their entire lives playing an mmo where you grind, have done a good job of telling the world how bad it is to grind. This game has a grind. If you enjoy the game, it's an enjoyable grind.

tldr: All in all a fantastic example of a decent crowdfunded game. It provides a gameplay concept (destroying cities with a giant robot x-com style) that would never see the light of day in the traditional model. Even though there are hits and misses, this is a great time to be a gamer.

review:
Okay, entweder man mag das Spiel und sieht über die momentanen Bugs hinweg oder man mag es nicht. Ich versuche ausführlich und ohne Fan-Boy Geschwafel mal die Punkte aufzuzählen.

Das Spiel hat zum momentanen Zeitpunkt eine Menge Bugs. Fehlerhafte Speicherstände, Wassereinheiten bewegen sich an Land. Die Monster (das Monster) ist manchmal ein wenig hakelig in der Steuerung. Es gibt kein Tutorial. Sound und andere Effekte lassen sich momentan nicht regeln. Es geht nur an oder aus. Die ein oder andere Eigenschaft mit der man das Monster ausstatten kann ist buggy. Und ab und zu wehrt sich eine Stadt auch mal nicht. Ich weiß nicht, ob das alles war, ansonsten schaut in den Bug-Thread.

Jetzt kommt das große ABER! Nicht alle haben diese Probleme. Ich selber bin zum Beispiel einzig von den Wassereinheiten an Land betroffen. UND... die Entwickler sind sehr nah am Spieler und fixen was das Zeug hält. Gehört sich auch so, denkt ihr? Weit gefehlt, wenn man manchen großen Publisher sieht.

Worum geht es in dem Spiel. Angelehnt an den (ich nenne ihn mal) Big-G, König der Monster Godzilla, erschafft ihr mit eurem verrückten Wissenschaftler einen Kaiju. Ein Monster. Mit dem wandert ihr über eine Weltkarte und müßt Städte in Schutt und Asche legen. Auch hier eine Warnung. Es artet ein wenig in "grinden" aus. Aber (meine Meinung) es lohnt sich. Jede Stadt ist anders. Jeder Stadtlevel (Tier 1 -...) hat andere Gegner für euren Kaiju parat. Bis hin zum Superpanzer oder andere gemeine Sachen. Es lohnt sich also länger als 2 Stunden zu spielen in denen man (so sagen es andere Rezensionen) angeblich eigentlich alles gesehen hat.

Nebenbei müßt ihr von den gesammelten Ressourcen eures Kaijus diesen ausbilden und immer neue bessere Gebäude in eurer Base bauen. Lagerhallen, bessere Reparaturstationen, Forschungslabore usw. und nicht zuletzt Verteidigungsanlagen für eure Base,. Denn es kommt der Tag, da schlägt die Kaiju Defense Force zurück und greift euch an.

Dieses Spiel hat wesentlich mehr Tiefgang als es zu Beginn den Anschein macht.

Jetzt doch ein wenig Fan-Boy... ich bin seit frühester Jugend Kaiju-Fan und spiele seit 20 Jahren am Computer (ausschließlich, deshalb kann ich ähnliche Monsterspiele für andere Plattformen nicht beurteilen) und auf ein solches Spiel habe ich immer gewartet. 

Wer mit ein paar Bugs leben kann, schon immer mal in die Rolle des Monsters schlüpfen und alles zerstören wollte, was ihm vor die Füße läuft UND ein wenig Ressourcenmanagement und Basebau betreiben wollte, der ist hier gut bedient.
Bei der momentanen Arbeit der Community (alles Fanboys und ein paar Trolle) sowie den sehr engagierten Entwicklern sehe ich hier echtes Potential.

Ihr bekommt einen Kaiju für euer Geld und es werden (nicht unendlich aber einige, 3 sind bereits terminiert) Kaijus nachkommen, so dass auch hier für Abwechslung gesorgt ist.

Wie immer mein Tip, glaubt dem Grummel nicht alles, sondern lest euch alle Rezensionen durch und stöbert im Communityforum zum Spiel. Dann trefft eure Entscheidung, dass Spiel zu kaufen oder nicht.

Ich für meinen Teil bereue es nicht und freue mich auf viele weitere Stunden Zerstörung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034908082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 2384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1961, 'last_played': 1465665467}
review:
F*** Yeah. This game has a lot going for it. There is something primal and satisfying about laying the smack down on an entire city and watching it react to your engine of destruction.  This game is a great buy as is, but with an active dev tweaking the game on a regular basis, Kaiju-A-GoGo is going well on the path to being an epic standalone in a genre I will coin S.O.S. or strategic overlord simulator.  

This is an early access review...yada yada yada, followed by yada.

Interface
Currently fairly simple and barebones. You load the game or start a new one. Aside from the options to turn off sound there are no real options to speak of. You can turn off the tutorial, but there is not enough of one yet to be considered. oh yeah.. be sure to save your game often, as there is not autosave. I repeat SAVE YOUR GAME ON A REGULAR BASIS, less your game crashes and you go back a year in game time...sigh. To dev, please please I beg you implement an autosave.

-Tutorial
 see above. The game is simple and forgiving enough that you can find your way, but it would be nice to have something to explain some of the mechanics, units, and world system.

-Graphics
I am going to be totally honest, I am slightly torn on the graphics. On the hardware side of things, it runs on my laptop for the most part, so I'm happy. Definitely not going to tax your turbocooled hyper threaded pc. The characters and monsters have a hand drawn feel. The cities, monster and military units are all isometric, but the units that actually move have about 4-6 frames, covering most angles. I like it, reminds me of the days of Mech Commander. 
The stylized look of the kaiju kaiju works, and I like it just fine, but it would be interesting to see if the design was a little realistic, and less comic or cartoon like. The animations are really cool for the attacks, and its really refreshing to see that quality and know that someone put in the time to make them. 

Sound
The background music of the game is cute and quirky, while the in game music is of the ominous type. Some variation or options would really enhance the mood of the game. Sound effects for the bang pow stuff, sounds like explosions and gunfire, so that works well. The attacks and abilities also have nice sound effects. In its essence, the game actually sounds like you are watching over a 200 metre behemoth tear apart a city.

Controls
I have a feeling that this is where this game is going to have a lot of attention, as the in game character is controlled via left mouse click while abilities are used with the number keys. Some will cry that more control should be allowed, like a WASD scheme, and while that would be a cool option if that would work with this style game(isometric), I don't know/think that it would translate very well. 

Bugs/Issues
- The base development and resource management aspect is fairly solid, although there are a couple issues with menu overlay- like when you are trying to build multiple buildings near each other when zoomed out.
-Crashes. the game has crashed on me a couple of times out of nowhere, leaving me to load from my previous save.
-SAVE SYSTEM- autosave would be a really great tool to prevent minor frustration from when the game crashes.
-In the assigning abilities menu, no info is available when you click on the abilities. To get that info you have to go to the training menu wheel and click on the ability you want info about. Can be a little confusing when you have a large wheel of abilities.

 As I write this, only one Kaiju is available, but I think 2 are on the way, with skins I hope/pray. You can tell I lot of thought and creativity went into the upgrading system, the game, the artwork. If I were ever to make a game, this would the game I would want to make. ciao

review:
UPDATE 7/9/2015 (version 1.0.13):
After much consideration I've changed my recommendation from "No" to "Yes".  That doesn't mean the game is perfect, or even fixes all the issues I had at launch, but I think in the last 2.5 months it has improved enough to be more good than bad and feel like a more complete game.

The controls are now more responsive, with the monster not ignoring so many clicks to tell it where to go.  They've added a second monster that plays pretty differently.  I'm not crashing frequently like I used to.  There are now proper sound sliders.  And many other bugs have been fixed alongside small additions and tweaks as you can see in the patch note posts.

I'd still love to see some better handling with a "flee/non-aggressive" mode toggle, as well as improving the base building and defenses part of the game, making it less grindy, improving readability/intuitiveness of the economy readouts and several other things.  

But overall I think enough has improved to make this worth a recommendation for the default price if you like giant monsters.  

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I was an Indie GoGo backer so I have been looking forward to this game for a while.  Unfortunately, I can't recommend it at launch.

By many measures this should be an Early Access game and not considered a "full" release.  The game only has one of the three promised kaiju, contains plenty of bugs, and it just does not feel done.

The controls are abysmal, frequently frustrating and responsible for multiple infuriatingly avoidable deaths already.  I have no idea how they thought this was a good control scheme.  Or the fact that you can't tell your monster to not attack things as you are trying to run for your life.  Whether your robot listens to you or not seems like pure luck.  Juck keep clicking and hope that it quits being so stupid.

I'm not personally a fan of the art style and I think the way that the monster is made up of several detached sprites instead of being a single animated sprite looks kind of bad.  The cities don't look bad, though, and when lots of things are burning and exploding it's pretty cool, especially at night.

As mentioned, I have run into several bugs.  I've had the game crash to desktop.  I've had cities where no enemy AI every spawned despite raising several Defcon levels.  There are Patrol Boats that drive right through ground terrain in many areas of cities.  There are no actual volume sliders for Music or Sound Volume.  

The game is also very grindy.  You'll have to keep attacking the same beginner cities for ages to build up enough resources to upgrade your island to then upgrade your monster.  But then when you inevitably die because of the poor controls you'll be knocked back a bit and have to build up resources again.  And be ready to spend most of your time speeding up and slowing down the passage of time as you repeatedly wait for basic things to complete, like walking to a city or repairing your monster.

Overall, this is just not ready.  There are some fun concepts here, but the actual gameplay is sorely lacking.  Hopefully in time this will be more fleshed out, better to control, and more polished overall.  Time will tell.

review:
This is a tablet game.  Or at least, it should be a tablet or phone game and not a PC game, the way the interface was done.

Anyone who says this is X-Com like has never actually played X-Com.  Not turn based, not squad combat, just one unit.  Yes, you build a base, and yes there's a globe and time clock where you select where to go... but it's not searching for and intercepting anything.  It's the same places you can go any time you want.

Pros:
- You're a mad scientist controlling a kaiju
- You get to smash cities quite thoroughly
- There is some customization of kaiju abilities
- Simple interface

Cons:
- Difficult to target attacking units
- Seems very grindy (at least early on)
- Did I mention repetitive?
- Incomplete, and should be Early Access as of April 25, 2015
- There's an ad when you exit you can't skip.  WTF.  I bought the game.
- Buggy.  For instance settings not saved, and constantly resetting the clock speed when you don't want it to.

I'm not going to comment on the graphics other than to say there's not much variation.  At all.

I'm not going to comment on their business model and how they're selling it.  They have pretty solid reasoning for it, though it is unconventional.

Is the game worth the current $12 price?  No.  Would it be worth $15 with all 3 kaiju?  No.  It should be a $5 iOS/Android market game and not a Steam game.

review:
This game is everything I've wanted for 20 years, ever since Mail Order Monsters on the C64/128.  I truly hope the developer continues to add more Kaiju after the 2 additional already planned and/or immediately begins taking my money for a sequel.

ETA:  Many many more hours in, I wanted to expand on this.  The game definitely lives up to it's X-com meets Evil Genius vibe.  Plenty of other reviews, and youtube footage explain or show how the game works if you want to get a feel for the actual gameplay.  I just want to say, if you enjoy giant monsters and enjoy strategy games, I can almost guarantee that you'll get at least some fun out of this game.  If you love giant monsters and mad science more than anything, you'll love this game because a decent game that feeds that love only comes along maybe once or twice a decade really.

At this point I feel the game has a very satisfying level of difficulty and rewards smart playing, while not being too punishing in the learning curve to figure out what exactly a smart play is going to be.

The original game balance was a touch easy, and in the first week it's been tweaked up and down a bit in response to player feedback.    While it's easy for some people to say 'Well, it should have been right the first time, why don't they have testers/what are the testers for?' Sometimes it isn't so easy to see the forest for the trees if you've been involved during the process.  Fresh eyes on the subject, and a wider range of play styles brings a lot of new info in and the devs have been HUGELY, AMAZINGLY responsive.  In fact, they've been so on the ball that I'm confident enough in continuing support for the game to want to be sure that they have the opportunity to do so and have bought 2 more copies for friends.  If this turns into a franchise with the legs to last I'll be quite happy, but after the effort the dev team has put in I feel confident that even if there were never another full game released in the series I'll be able to play it years from now and find bugfixes and compatibility updates for Windows 2035 HyperWeb Edition.  Well worth the money I've spent.

review:
Interesting and different kind of game. 

You start off attacking Alaska with limited abilities and limited resources. This quickly builds as you collect resources from the cities you destroy and take them back with you to your base to construct facilities for production, defense and storage. 

Also, one building type in particular gives you ability enhancements. From here, you will purchase and train your Kaiju in skills chosen from a tech tree. All the cities are different and have a variety of difficulty levels. You are attacked by various military units and there is quite a few. You can only pick the one Kaiju for the moment but more are coming in Summer. Here's my pro/con list:

pros:

- Unique & successful idea set into motion.
- Easy to start but yet pretty deep
- Really fun destroying the cities (each city has special buildings or landmarks)
- Can advance your Kaiju and make him stronger and stronger
- The art style is interesting and looks good
- There are many cities to conquer and some simply can not be conquered from the start

cons: 

- loading times are a bit long
- controls can be a bit wonky why you are trying to destroy a military unit attacking you
- UI controls for the base are a bit confusing (I didn't realize I had to build a advance facility to get to Tier 2 skills until later that I would have liked)
- the game crashed a couple of times due to a bug when leaving a city (twice but isn't a huge issue)
- some cities regenerate pretty quickly (rebuild and restore morale) 

But all in all, it is a fun game that you should try if you like action mixed with base building and an a bit of an RPG element. It is a game for all ages!

author: {'steamid': '76561197981519088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1481285451}
review:
UPDATE: The devs have been hard at work so far on this game so I have updated this review for my current opinion. Earlier I recommended the game but to buy later when stuff was fixed, well lots of it has been fixed really fast since release.

UPDATE 2: My DLC concerns are out of the window as of May 5th 2015 due to the next two monsters being free for current owners of the game, and the price will go up for new buyers by $1 per monster which really isn't that bad at all. More fixes and balancing was done, and a free skin for the first monster was given free to current Steam owners until May 8th. The game is a much smoother experience and is coming along nicely and at a good rate. I'm actually surprised, being so cynical about the current state of the gaming industry it's really rare to see devs do so good and honestly makes me more than glad I bought this game on release day. The issue I had with 'depth' isn't as bad as it may sound if you read my original review below, but when I said 'deeper than it looks but not deep enough'  I want to revise that to 'deeper than it looks and deep enough for most'. Original review below for those still reading.

Original review:
I do recommend this game but there is a few caveats (UPDATE: 100% recommend the game at this point to anyone who would ask). It is deeper than it looks but not deep enough in some spots (UPDATE: revised above in my 2nd update of this review). It's like a reverse XCOM in the sense that you are trying to destabilize the world instead of save it, but you only have one base to operate from. That is a way to describe it, it's almost like you are playing the alien side in the original XCOM with your hidden base and once found will be assaulted.

DLC are advertised and that bums me out since we might not get anything for free at a later date, that is enough to scare off many people because we all have seen how well that worked for Evolve (UPDATE: As of my 2nd review update above this is not a problem at all, and definitely nothing like Evolve). Maybe the devs will have a better DLC model, but most of the time DLC just bums me out from purchasing any at all. Still this game is easy to lose a time in as it is now. Gameplay is simple and satisfying, this game can work as pick-up and go where you smash a single city or for extended gaming sessions and to top it off this shouldn't require a powerful PC. A few bugs here and there, nothing bad found yet. They are getting squashed at a regular rate though. I will swear there is nothing quite like controlling a mecha-godzilla stomping around a city while drinking some beer, that is seriously some good times.

So while I do recommend this game I would tell anyone who asked to buy it if you really dig some vids that are out now and if you are on the fence then wait on a sale maybe but the price is still good (UPDATE: I'd tell anyone this is a good game experience at this point and is getting better, 100% recommended purchase) Since there will be DLC in a year or so we might see a DLC pack on sale or a GOTY edition. At this point the game could develop well or not, anymore you never know even with companies with good track records. But the price is good, $13 to start. Wait and see how these DLC roll out and see how many features get added, but the developers are doing very good on stabilizing and balancing the game in it's current state and the prospects for the future of this game are much better than others we have seen recently I shall not mention. If I were to go in the past for a do-over I'd still buy the game when I did, I call it a good purchase for myself. (UPDATE: Game is being taken care of, bugs and glitches are being squashed at a fast pace and additions are being made in a fast manner and I consider this one of my better game purchases so far in 2015)

author: {'steamid': '76561198031905307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 15739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5162, 'last_played': 1500109860}
review:
Full Disclosure: I backed the Indiegogo campaign and played the game prior to release!
Edit: Updated after the 1.03 patrol hotfix. 

Updated Bit: 
 - You can now recycle unwanted buildings at your lair, and there are more tooltips for the secret base buildings. 
- For those who were worried, volume sliders are in. 
- Threatening cities (once you have built a properly dangerous reputation) is in, provided you build the proper base facility. 
- Stupid play is still stupid play: Don't expect stomping only small apartment complexes to give you the resources you need. Tactical and strategic city-stomping is rewarded... time is a resource before city defenders show up, so go for the JUICY targets like universities, banks, and power plants. 
- Core gameplay is in and solid. Technical issues (slowdown spikes on some rigs, very strong patrols) seem to have been addressed, but this game still has some rough edges. If you require prefect functionality, this game is not for you. 
- Still an easy recommend if you are into city-stomping and varied monster training. 

Pros: 

- First Kaiju City Stomper/Base Building game in ages (ever?)
- Kaiju is not a static creature, but one the player nurtures and develops through resource gathering and training
- Training does not follow a fixed path! Game has 99+ abilities for the Kaiju, and the player is only expected to unlock around 33 on a normal run. Abilities are unlocked via a web, whereby you can't simply rush to the ability you want. Prereqs must be unlocked too. 
- The world is not JUST your punching bag. Each region is building its own unique Kaiju to thwart you! There are six regions, each with a different mix of defense units. 
- Resources! 5 you gather (Power, Knowledge, Money, "Organics", and Purpletonium) and one you can only spend- time! After five years of raiding and conquering, the Kaiju Defense Force is coming for you and your secret base.
- Unique city layouts! Each city is different and persistent, so the approach to optimally convert Caracas will be very different to the strategy needed for Seattle. Player decisions and needs matter and the game rewards considered city destruction. (Juicy targets may be mostly hidden behind terrain or skyrises, so there is an element of treasure hunting/Where's Waldo?)
- Base Building: The way you lose is if your secret Lair is destroyed, so you will need to build both defensive and production buildings to properly suceed. I don't have much experience with base defense yet, but you can make walls and at least 3 defensive turret types. 
- Made by Kerberos Productions as an Indie! KP has a fantastic track record of support for their indie titles, both tech and free content. (Look at The Pit, their roguelike, which had numerous updates and tweaks in addition to expansions for over two years.)
- You get to stomp cities as a giant monster! Did I mention that? I think I did...

Cons
- Some sound effect kinks remain. The sound of tank tracks, for example, can play in the background even when you have left a city you are fighting. 
- Kaiju control is very much "go there and bash things," no way to differentiate auto-attacks from just defenders or just buildings. This is a minor quibble though, as the player has pinpoint targeting control of most of the activated abilities you research. Can make the first few cities frustrating. 
- Will not cure cancer. 

Overall: A polished city-stomper with lots of variety and opportunities for skilled play to matter. All delivered in a quirky B movie style with lots of explosions. If you like this style of game, a wholehearted reccommendation!

review:

Yesterday, I had the chance to play Kaiju-a-GoGo and interview the lead designer, Martin Cirulis. I had no idea what I was getting myself into, or just how much of a blast the game would be.

Kaiju-a-GoGo is the kind of city-crunching, monument-stomping, laserbeam-shooting, cutely-terrifying Kaiju'em Up I've been waiting for. With a surprising amount of depth under the hood aside from STOMP STUFF KILL THINGS (things burn easier in dry parts of the world--who knew!), it captures the raw simplicity of, well, stomping stuff and killing things without becoming one-note.

I may be on a watchlist now after telling my friends charming things like "Make sure to burn the houses in Wellington," or "Have you tried attacking Seattle yet?", but that's okay! All I need is one more upgrade before I sign off for the day...

One more power plant...
One more city...
One more region...

10/10, would Kaiju myself onto a watchlist again.

review:
OK so if you've always wanted to decimate a city with  giant robot monster, this is the game for you.

A few things I didn't expect going in:

1) The level of detail. In terms of managing your secret base, upgrading and repairing your kaiju, there is a lot to do and consider. 

2) How much actual fun causing mayhem in a seemingly helpless city is.

3) Level of difficulty. It's not quite as easy as it seems either. Cities will ramp up their efforts to repel you as you tear down more and more of their infrastructure (why are they so hostile?). So expect infantry, combat jeeps, tanks, helicopters and more to try to take a piece out of your precious Kaiju.

Apart from the aforementioned stuff, the art style and attention to detail in the layouts of the cities is very fitting and well-done. Who doesn't like goofy mad scientists bent on world destruction?

To summarize: Get this game if you want a casual, yet deep strategy experience that you can easily play in small bites or marathon sessions. It's strangely addicting. Just don't cackle in glee with your friends or family around. They...probably won't understand... Anyway, just get this game. You won't regret it.

P.S. Did I mention the X-Com like world map and  time compression system? I'll do that next time.

review:
This is a spiritual successor to Crush Crumble & Chomp, and the Epyx Movie Monster Game which you might remember from the C64.  Somewhat of an inverse-XCOM because you're the bad guy trying to defeat the world by attacking cities and building your secret island base.  You can look all day long for a strategy game where you stomp through a city as a giant monster... I'll wait...  right, there aren't any others.  So, if that's your thing then this is your game.

It's evident that Canadians made this, because all the N. American cities are the ones with good hockey teams.  The soundtrack is fun, and there's no mistaking that it's considerably inspired by Toho's own soundtracks.  Buildings burn NICELY, and the fire propagates, so you'll have some pretty epic views of burning cities at night.  Multiple tiers of unlockable powers - breath weapons, eye beams, armor, shields, big guns.  The game has a single Kaiju in it now, a Mechagodzilla inspired robozilla, and down the road they'll release at least two more - maybe more.  Maybe if enough of us chant "Cthulhu" in the comments that can happen.  :-)

It works, it's fun, and it's the only game like it... so it's a pretty easy $12ish to spend.
